description.selection:
# Template Selection

Modern React SPA starter

Use when:
- Client-side only apps with no backend persistence
- Static apps, dashboards
- Simple, fast Vite projects

Avoid when:
- SEO/SSR landing pages
- Heavy backend/server needs
- Data persistence of any kind is required on server side

Built with:
- React Router, ShadCN UI, Tailwind, Lucide Icons, ESLint, Vite
description.usage:
# Usage

## Built with
- React Router 6, ShadCN UI, Tailwind, Lucide Icons, ESLint, Vite
- Platform-agnostic backend support (can be deployed to Cloudflare Workers, Google App Engine, or any hosting platform)

## Restrictions
- Tailwind: define custom colors in `tailwind.config.js` (not in `index.css`)

## Styling
- Responsive, accessible
- Prefer ShadCN components; Tailwind utilities for custom parts
- Icons from `lucide-react`
- Error boundaries are already implemented

## Animation
- Use `framer-motion` for small interactions when needed

## Components
- Import from `@/components/ui/*` (ShadCN). Avoid reinventing components.

## Example
```tsx
import { Button } from '@/components/ui/button'
import { Card, CardContent } from '@/components/ui/card'

export function Example() {
  return (
    <Card className="max-w-sm">
      <CardContent className="p-4 flex gap-2">
        <Button>Click</Button>
      </CardContent>
    </Card>
  )
}
```

## Backend (optional)
- If you add backend routes, do it in `worker/index.ts` (or your platform's entry point). Follow the existing pattern carefully to avoid breakage.
- The backend can be deployed to Cloudflare Workers, Google App Engine, or any Node.js-compatible hosting platform.

description.selection:
# Template Selection

Full-stack template with seeded Firestore collections and counters. Defaults to Google Cloud but stays portable to Cloudflare Workers or any hosting provider via datastore abstractions.

Use when:
- You want demo seed endpoints out of the box
- The backend needs CRUD APIs across multiple entities plus counters
- You may switch providers later by updating environment variables

Avoid when:
- You only need a frontend SPA
- SEO/SSR marketing sites (use the Next.js template)

Built with:
- React Router, ShadCN UI, Tailwind, Lucide Icons, ESLint, Vite
- Hono API + datastore abstraction (Firestore default, HTTP provider optional)
description.usage:
# Usage

## Overview
Full-stack React + Hono template with a seeded datastore abstraction. Defaults to Google Cloud Firestore (REST) but can target any HTTPS-accessible provider via environment variables.
- Frontend: React Router 6 + TypeScript + ShadCN UI
- Backend: Hono APIs using `createDataStore` helpers
- Shared: Types in `shared/types.ts`

## Demo Content
- Replace `HomePage.tsx` / `DemoPage.tsx` with production UI
- Update mock data in `shared/mock-data.ts`
- Review seed logic in `worker/entities.ts`

## Key Files
- `worker/core-utils.ts` / `worker/datastore/*` – datastore configuration
- `worker/entities.ts` – seed helpers, CRUD, counters
- `worker/userRoutes.ts` – API routes
- `shared/types.ts` – shared DTOs

## Environment Variables
Firestore (default):
- `FIRESTORE_PROJECT_ID`
- `FIRESTORE_CLIENT_EMAIL`
- `FIRESTORE_PRIVATE_KEY_B64` (base64-encoded PEM)
- Optional: `FIRESTORE_DATABASE_ID`, `FIRESTORE_API_ENDPOINT`

HTTP provider (MongoDB Data API, custom REST, etc.):
- `DATA_PROVIDER=http`
- `DATA_HTTP_BASE_URL`
- `DATA_HTTP_API_KEY` (optional)
- `DATA_HTTP_HEADERS_JSON` (optional JSON string)

## Example Route
```ts
import { ok, bad } from './core-utils';
import { ensureSeed, listDemoItems } from './entities';

app.get('/api/demo', async (c) => {
  await ensureSeed(c.env);
  const page = await listDemoItems(c.env, { limit: 25 });
  return ok(c, page);
});
```

## Deployment
- App Engine: `bun run build && gcloud app deploy`
- Cloudflare Workers: `bun run build && wrangler deploy`

Google Cloud is the default while the abstraction keeps storage flexible for other providers.

description.selection:
# Template Selection

General-purpose full-stack template with Google Cloud Firestore as the default data store. The backend exposes a pluggable storage abstraction so you can point the same code at Firestore, MongoDB Data API, or any HTTPS-accessible service by swapping environment variables.

Use when:
- You want App Engine + Firestore out of the box
- The backend needs CRUD APIs with multi-entity persistence
- You prefer declarative templates that can pivot between providers

Avoid when:
- You only need a frontend SPA with no backend
- SEO/SSR landing pages (use Next.js template)

Built with:
- React Router, ShadCN UI, Tailwind, Lucide Icons, ESLint, Vite
- Hono API + pluggable data store (Firestore default, HTTP proxy optional)
- Compatible with Cloudflare Workers, Google App Engine, or any hosting platform that can supply the required environment variables
description.usage:
# Usage

## Overview
Full-stack React + Hono starter wired for App Engine + Firestore. The backend exposes a data-store abstraction that defaults to Firestore but can target any HTTPS-accessible database (MongoDB Data API, Supabase REST, custom microservice) by updating environment variables.
- Frontend: React Router 6 + TypeScript + ShadCN UI
- Backend: Hono APIs running on Workers or Node
- Storage: Firestore REST integration (default) + HTTP proxy provider

## Demo Content
- Replace `HomePage.tsx` / `DemoPage.tsx` with real UI
- Swap out `shared/mock-data.ts`
- Update demo API routes in `worker/user-routes.ts`

## Key Files
- `worker/core-utils.ts` / `worker/datastore/*` – provider configuration
- `worker/entities.ts` – repository helpers (users + chats)
- `worker/user-routes.ts` – API routes calling the data store
- `shared/types.ts` – shared DTOs

## Environment Variables
**Firestore (default)**
- `DATA_PROVIDER=firestore`
- `FIRESTORE_PROJECT_ID`
- `FIRESTORE_CLIENT_EMAIL`
- `FIRESTORE_PRIVATE_KEY_B64` (base64-encoded PEM)
- `FIRESTORE_DATABASE_ID` (optional, defaults to `(default)`)
- `FIRESTORE_API_ENDPOINT` (optional override/emulator)

**HTTP provider (MongoDB Data API, etc.)**
- `DATA_PROVIDER=http`
- `DATA_HTTP_BASE_URL`
- `DATA_HTTP_API_KEY` (optional)
- `DATA_HTTP_HEADERS_JSON` (optional JSON string)

## Adding Routes
```ts
import { ok, bad } from './core-utils';
import { createUser } from './entities';

app.post('/api/users', async (c) => {
  const { name } = await c.req.json<{ name?: string }>();
  if (!name?.trim()) return bad(c, 'name required');
  const user = await createUser(c.env, { id: crypto.randomUUID(), name: name.trim() });
  return ok(c, user);
});
```

## Deployment
- App Engine: `npm run build && gcloud app deploy`
- Cloudflare Workers: `bun run build && wrangler deploy`

Ensure identical environment variables exist in each platform. Firestore credentials must be stored as secrets (`wrangler secret put`, Secret Manager).

## Custom Providers
Switch `DATA_PROVIDER` to `http` and point to your own HTTPS data service; the rest of the template stays untouched.

Google Cloud remains the default while the abstraction keeps storage flexible and declarative.

description.selection:
# Template Selection

Full-stack template with Firestore-backed datastore for simple global-state demos (counter, collections). Ships with Google Cloud App Engine defaults but stays portable to Cloudflare Workers or any hosting platform via provider-agnostic abstractions.

Use when:
- You need a lightweight backend with seeded data and counters
- You want Google Cloud defaults but may deploy elsewhere
- You prefer to keep infrastructure flexible through env vars

Avoid when:
- You only need a frontend SPA
- SEO/SSR landing pages (choose the Next.js template instead)

Built with:
- React Router, ShadCN UI, Tailwind, Lucide Icons, ESLint, Vite
- Hono API + datastore abstraction (Firestore default, HTTP provider optional)
description.usage:
# Usage

## Overview
Full-stack React application with server-side state management powered by a provider-agnostic datastore abstraction.
- Frontend: React Router 6 + TypeScript + ShadCN UI
- Backend: Hono-based API using `createDataStore` (Firestore default, HTTP fallback)
- Shared: Types in `shared/types.ts`
- Deployment: Works on Google App Engine, Cloudflare Workers, or any hosting platform

## Demo Content
- Replace `HomePage.tsx` / `DemoPage.tsx` with production UI
- Remove or adapt mock data in `shared/mock-data.ts`
- Update demo API routes in `worker/userRoutes.ts` and helpers in `worker/entities.ts`

## Key Files
- `worker/core-utils.ts` / `worker/datastore/*` – datastore configuration
- `worker/entities.ts` – demo repository helpers (items + counter)
- `worker/userRoutes.ts` – HTTP routes
- `shared/types.ts` – shared DTOs

## Environment Variables
Firestore (default):
- `FIRESTORE_PROJECT_ID`
- `FIRESTORE_CLIENT_EMAIL`
- `FIRESTORE_PRIVATE_KEY_B64` (base64-encoded PEM)
- Optional: `FIRESTORE_DATABASE_ID`, `FIRESTORE_API_ENDPOINT`

HTTP provider (MongoDB Data API, custom REST, etc.):
- `DATA_PROVIDER=http`
- `DATA_HTTP_BASE_URL`
- `DATA_HTTP_API_KEY` (optional)
- `DATA_HTTP_HEADERS_JSON` (optional JSON string)

## Adding Routes
```ts
import { ok, bad } from './core-utils';
import { upsertDemoItem } from './entities';

app.post('/api/demo', async (c) => {
  const { name } = await c.req.json<{ name?: string }>();
  if (!name?.trim()) return bad(c, 'name required');
  const item = await upsertDemoItem(c.env, { id: crypto.randomUUID(), name: name.trim(), value: 0 });
  return ok(c, item);
});
```

## Deployment
- App Engine: `bun run build && gcloud app deploy`
- Cloudflare Workers: `bun run build && wrangler deploy`

Google Cloud remains the default while the abstraction keeps storage flexible and declarative.

description.selection:
# Template Selection Guidelines

This template offers a streamlined and performant foundation for building beautiful, responsive landing pages with modern animations and iconography.

* Use this template when you need:
  * High-performance server-side heavy projects and dashboards
  * Pages optimized for SEO with server-rendered content
  * Responsive design with smooth scrolling and page transitions
  * Easily customizable layouts for product launches, waitlists, or portfolios
  * Design-first experiences with animation and interactivity

* Do not use it for:
  * Lightweight, mostly client side heavy projects
  * Static pages

* Built with:
  * **Next.js (Page Router)** for hybrid static & server rendering, built-in SEO, and routing
  * **Tailwind CSS** for rapid UI development with utility-first styling
  * **Lucide Icons** for sleek, consistent iconography
  * **Framer Motion** for intuitive, production-ready animations
  * **TypeScript** and **ESLint** for type safety and code quality
description.usage:
# Usage instructions You can start editing the page by modifying `pages/index.tsx`. The page auto-updates as you edit the file. API routes can be accessed on [http://localhost:3000/api/hello](http://localhost:3000/api/hello). This endpoint can be edited in `pages/api/hello.ts`. The `pages/api` directory is mapped to `/api/*`. Files in this directory are treated as API routes instead of React pages. - Built with: * Next.js (Page Router) for hybrid static/server rendering and SEO optimization * Tailwind CSS** for utility-first styling and rapid prototyping * Lucide Icons** (React) for modern, consistent iconography * Framer Motion** for smooth, production-ready animations * ESLint and TypeScript for linting and type safety out of the box * ShadCN UI** (v2.3.0) for customizable and accessible UI components built on Radix UI primitives - Restrictions: * When including `tailwind.config.js`, **hardcode custom colors** directly in the config file – do **not** define them in `globals.css` unless specified * Next.js cannot infer props for React Components, so YOU MUST provide default props * Use Page router and not App router - Styling: * Must generate **fully responsive** and accessible layouts * Use Shadcn preinstalled components rather than writing custom ones when possible * Use **Tailwind's spacing, layout, and typography utilities** for all components - Components: * All Shadcn components are available and can be imported from @/components/ui/... * Do not write custom components if shadcn components are available * Icons from Lucide should be imported directly from `lucide-react` - Animation: * Use `framer-motion`'s `motion` components to animate sections on scroll or page load * You can integrate variants and transitions using Tailwind utility classes alongside motion props --- Components available: ```sh $ ls -1 src/components/ui accordion.tsx alert-dialog.tsx alert.tsx aspect-ratio.tsx avatar.tsx badge.tsx breadcrumb.tsx button.tsx calendar.tsx card.tsx carousel.tsx chart.tsx checkbox.tsx collapsible.tsx command.tsx context-menu.tsx dialog.tsx drawer.tsx dropdown-menu.tsx form.tsx hover-card.tsx input-otp.tsx input.tsx label.tsx menubar.tsx navigation-menu.tsx pagination.tsx popover.tsx progress.tsx radio-group.tsx resizable.tsx scroll-area.tsx select.tsx separator.tsx sheet.tsx sidebar.tsx skeleton.tsx slider.tsx sonner.tsx switch.tsx table.tsx tabs.tsx textarea.tsx toast.tsx toggle-group.tsx toggle.tsx tooltip.tsx ``` ### Usage Example ```tsx file="src/components/Hero.tsx" 'use client' import { motion } from 'framer-motion' import { ArrowRightIcon } from 'lucide-react' import { Button } from '@/components/ui/button' export function Hero() { return (

Build Stunning Landing Pages Fast

A modern Next.js starter with Tailwind, Framer Motion, and Lucide.

) } ```

description.selection:
# Template Selection

Multi-platform AI chat template with Firestore-backed persistence and tool calling. Defaults to Google Cloud App Engine + Firestore, but can run on Cloudflare Workers or any host by swapping environment variables.

Use when:
- You need streaming AI chat with persistent history
- Tool/function calling (SerpAPI, MCP, custom REST) is required
- You want to plug into Google AI Gateway, OpenAI, or other compatible providers

Avoid when:
- You only need a static site or simple non-persistent chatbot
- You do not control API keys for the AI gateway

Built with:
- React + Vite + Shadcn/UI + Framer Motion
- Hono backend with datastore abstraction (Firestore default, HTTP fallback)
- OpenAI SDK compatible with Google Cloud AI Gateway
- Optional MCP client integration for external tools
description.usage:
# Usage

## Overview
Full-stack AI chatbot with streaming responses, session management, and Firestore persistence.
- Frontend: React Router + Shadcn/UI + Tailwind
- Backend: Hono routes under `/api/chat/:sessionId/*` and `/api/sessions/*`
- Storage: Firestore (default) or HTTP datastore via env vars
- AI: OpenAI SDK pointed at Google Cloud AI Gateway (or compatible endpoint)

## Key Files
- `worker/userRoutes.ts` – chat & session APIs
- `worker/chat.ts` – AI pipeline + tool execution
- `worker/sessionStore.ts` – Firestore CRUD helpers
- `worker/tools.ts` – SerpAPI + MCP integration
- `src/lib/chat.ts` – frontend API client
- `src/pages/DemoPage.tsx` – demo UI

## Environment Variables
Required:
- `CF_AI_BASE_URL`, `CF_AI_API_KEY`
- Firestore secrets (`FIRESTORE_PROJECT_ID`, `FIRESTORE_CLIENT_EMAIL`, `FIRESTORE_PRIVATE_KEY_B64`) unless using HTTP provider
Optional:
- `SERPAPI_KEY` for web search tool
- HTTP provider overrides (`DATA_PROVIDER=http`, `DATA_HTTP_BASE_URL`, etc.)

## Routes
- `GET /api/chat/:sessionId/messages`
- `POST /api/chat/:sessionId/chat` (streaming supported)
- `POST /api/chat/:sessionId/model`
- `DELETE /api/chat/:sessionId/clear`
- Session CRUD under `/api/sessions`

## Notes
- Persisted conversations live in Firestore collections
- Add new MCP servers via `worker/mcp-client.ts`
- Remind users about AI rate limits in the UI

Google Cloud defaults are provided, but the template stays portable across hosting providers through environment configuration.
